sentence:
Recent articles are much more likely to be OA than their older counterparts (see Results ‘How does Open Access vary by year of publication?’ below).What types of Open Access are most common?
The proportion of OA by subtype is relatively similar across the samples, as shown in Fig. 1 and Table 3.

Access type
Crossref-DOI All journal articles with Crossref DOIs, all years. (“Articles with DOIs” in Fig. 1)
WoS-DOIs All citable WoS articles with DOIs, 2009–2015
Unpaywall-DOIs All articles accessed by Unpaywall users over a 1-week period in 2017



Estimate
95% CI
Estimate
95% CI
Estimate
95% CI

Gold OA

Green OA

52.7–53.3



Open in a new tabHow does Open Access vary by year of publication?
Figure 2 presents the number (Fig. 2A) and proportion (Fig. 2B) of papers by access category and publication date.
Second, many articles cannot be legally self-archived until a certain number of months after publication; this embargoing likely influences the apparent plateau in Green shown in Fig. 2.
As we can see in Fig. 3A, the largest publishers by volume publish the most OA articles by volume, led by Elsevier.
As a proportion of all articles published (Fig. 3B), however, PLOS and Hindawi distinguish themselves as being the only publishers in the top 20 with 100% OA.
Figure 4 displays our results.
Figure 4 also highlights the popularity of Green OA in disciplines like physics and mathematics, where more than one fifth of papers are available only through online repositories (mainly arXiv).
Figure 5 below describes these findings.
Open in a new tabThese trends vary over time, however, as shown in Fig. 6.

Recent articles are much more likely to be OA than their older counterparts (see Results ‘How does Open Access vary by year of publication?’ below).What types of Open Access are most common?
The proportion of OA by subtype is relatively similar across the samples, as shown in Fig. 1 and Table 3.

WoS-DOIs All citable WoS articles with DOIs, 2009–2015
Unpaywall-DOIs All articles accessed by Unpaywall users over a 1-week period in 2017

How does Open Access vary by year of publication?
Figure 2 presents the number (Fig. 2A) and proportion (Fig. 2B) of papers by access category and publication date.
Second, many articles cannot be legally self-archived until a certain number of months after publication; this embargoing likely influences the apparent plateau in Green shown in Fig. 2.

As we can see in Fig. 3A, the largest publishers by volume publish the most OA articles by volume, led by Elsevier.
As a proportion of all articles published (Fig. 3B), however, PLOS and Hindawi distinguish themselves as being the only publishers in the top 20 with 100% OA.
